chapter.title: Self-disclosure decision-making process
chapter.content:
Self-disclosure decision-making process

Self-disclosure is a multifaceted decision-making process. It takes effective communication skills, since an individual must determine where, when, what, and how to self-disclose.

chapter.title: Where to self-disclose
chapter.content:
Where to self-disclose

Let’s first look at where to self-disclose.

chapter.title: Where to self-disclose LD in a work setting
chapter.content:
Where to self-disclose LD in a work setting

It is important to find the appropriate place to self-disclose. In a work setting, the human resources office would be appropriate. If there is no human resources office, an individual should self-disclose to the employer directly.

chapter.title: Where to self-disclose LD in an educational setting
chapter.content:
Where to self-disclose LD in an educational setting

In an educational setting, there may be a disability office. Many large universities have such offices. At smaller schools, an individual should speak to the person in charge of intake or ask for the appropriate person to speak with in regard to disabilities. An individual can also self-disclose to counselors, teachers, and tutors.

chapter.title: Difference in choosing a teacher vs. a counselor or disabilities services provider
chapter.content:
Difference in choosing a teacher vs. a counselor or disabilities services provider

Consider for a moment:  given the difficulties many individuals with learning disabilities may have with self-disclosure, what would be the difference between choosing to disclose to a teacher vs. a counselor or a disabilities services provider?

chapter.title: Programs should collect and share information with teachers
chapter.content:
Programs should collect and share information with teachers

In any program, there should be an administrator or counselor responsible for collecting documentation and sharing that information with appropriate teachers. While an individual with a learning disability certainly should communicate directly with teachers, it is important to participate in any program’s system for collecting and sharing documentation in support of persons with disabilities.

chapter.title: When to self-disclose
chapter.content:
When to self-disclose

Wherever an individual is self-disclosing, some times are more advantageous than others. Let’s take a look at when to self-disclose.

chapter.title: Individuals should self-disclose before experiencing difficulty
chapter.content:
Individuals should self-disclose before experiencing difficulty

It is most effective to self-disclose before experiencing difficulty to avoid negative outcomes that might be prevented through appropriate accommodations.

An individual should self-disclose prior to enrollment or during the interview process if he or she needs accommodations during the application or interview process. There is a risk to self-disclosure at this point because the individual could be rejected based on a lack of understanding of the disability or accommodation needs, despite the laws.

If the individual anticipates needing accommodations to complete classes or do a job, it would be important to self-disclose at the time of enrollment or when employment begins so that needed accommodations can be put in place.

People can also self-disclose after enrollment or during employment once they realize that they need accommodations to be successful.

chapter.title: What to self-disclose
chapter.content:
What to self-disclose

Now that we’ve talked about where and when to self-disclose, let’s discuss the “what.” This is the specific information an individual with a learning disability should self-disclose.

chapter.title: Information to discuss when disclosing LD
chapter.content:
Information to discuss when disclosing LD

If an individual decides to disclose his or her learning disability, it is important to discuss:

  • information about the disability, including assessments and documentation of the disability;
  • types of academic and employment-related accommodations that have worked in the past;
  • types of academic and employment-related accommodations the individual may anticipate needing; and
  • how the learning disability affects the individual’s capacity to learn, study and/or work effectively.

chapter.title: Self-disclosure at different levels
chapter.content:
Self-disclosure at different levels

Disclosure can take place at different levels of program services. At the program level, an individual should provide diagnostic information, accommodations, etc.

An individual can also self-disclose at the level of the direct service provider. Typically this disclosure is limited to how the learning disability affects the individual’s capacity to learn, study, and work effectively.

Note that in ALL cases, documentation should be kept confidential, which is an upcoming topic.

chapter.title: How to self-disclose
chapter.content:
How to self-disclose

We’ve discussed where, when and what to self-disclose, but how should a person with a learning disability self-disclose?

chapter.title: Confidentiality is important for self-disclosure
chapter.content:
Confidentiality is important for self-disclosure

How to self-disclose is up to the individual; however, since confidentiality is a vital piece of self-disclosure, an individual may prefer to set up a face-to-face meeting.

If an individual decides to disclose his or her learning disability, it is important that the conversation takes place in a private space and that there is enough time for a two-way conversation. If possible, the individual should present documentation of the learning disability at the time of disclosure.
